name: Attacking the Person (Ad Hominem)
description: Rejecting an idea by criticizing the person instead of the idea.
example: You can't trust Maria's opinion on climate change—she failed science in high school.
correctedExample: Maria's past grades aren't relevant. Let's look at the data she presents on climate change.
explanation: The argument dismisses Maria's point based on her personal history, not the actual topic.

name: Misrepresenting the Argument (Strawman)
description: Changing someone's argument to make it easier to attack.
example: John says we should be more careful with military spending. Sarah replies, 'John wants to leave us defenseless!'
correctedExample: John is suggesting caution, not eliminating the military. We should address his actual point.
explanation: Sarah distorts John's view into something extreme and unrelated.

name: It’s True Because It’s Popular (Appeal to Popularity)
description: Claiming something is true just because many people believe it.
example: Everyone says this new diet works, so it must be effective.
correctedExample: We should check if there's scientific evidence that the diet works.
explanation: Popularity doesn't prove something is true.

name: Only Two Choices (False Dilemma)
description: Saying there are only two options when more actually exist.
example: You're either with us or against us.
correctedExample: Someone can support some ideas without agreeing with everything.
explanation: This oversimplifies complex positions into two extremes.

name: Going in Circles (Begging the Question)
description: Repeating the conclusion as the reason, without offering evidence.
example: The law is just because it's the law.
correctedExample: We should explain why the law is fair or beneficial.
explanation: It assumes what it’s trying to prove.

name: If This, Then Disaster (Slippery Slope)
description: Saying a small step will lead to something extreme without proof.
example: If we allow students to redo assignments, soon they’ll expect to retake every test too.
correctedExample: Redoing some assignments doesn’t mean all rules will disappear. Let’s focus on the policy itself.
explanation: It jumps from a small change to an exaggerated outcome.

name: Jumping to Conclusions (Hasty Generalization)
description: Making a broad claim based on little evidence.
example: I met two rude people from that city—everyone there must be rude.
correctedExample: Two people aren’t enough to judge an entire city.
explanation: It assumes a general rule based on a few cases.

name: Trust Me, I’m Important (Appeal to Authority)
description: Using a famous person’s opinion as proof, even when it’s not relevant.
example: A celebrity said this vitamin works, so it must be true.
correctedExample: We should look for medical studies, not celebrity opinions.
explanation: Being famous doesn’t make someone right on every topic.

name: This Happened, So That Must’ve Caused It (Post Hoc)
description: Assuming that just because one thing happened before another, it caused it.
example: I wore my lucky socks and we won the game, so the socks caused it.
correctedExample: Winning was probably due to skill, not socks.
explanation: Timing doesn’t prove cause.

name: Using Feelings Instead of Reasons (Appeal to Emotion)
description: Trying to win an argument by stirring emotions instead of logic.
example: Think of the children—we must ban all video games!
correctedExample: Let’s look at data on video games and behavior, not just emotional reactions.
explanation: It replaces reasoning with emotional pressure.

name: Changing the Subject (Red Herring)
description: Distracting from the main point with unrelated information.
example: Why worry about pollution when unemployment is still high?
correctedExample: Pollution and unemployment are both important but should be discussed separately.
explanation: It diverts attention from the original topic.

name: Everyone’s Doing It (Bandwagon)
description: Arguing something is right because other people are doing it.
example: Everyone’s using this app, so it must be the best.
correctedExample: Let’s look at the features and reviews, not just popularity.
explanation: Following the crowd doesn’t guarantee quality.

name: Not the Same Thing (False Equivalence)
description: Treating two very different things as if they’re equal.
example: Why ban smoking? Caffeine is a drug too.
correctedExample: Smoking and caffeine have different health impacts and regulations.
explanation: It compares things that aren’t truly equal.

name: Prove Me Wrong (Burden of Proof)
description: Making a claim and saying others must disprove it.
example: Aliens exist unless you can prove they don't.
correctedExample: Extraordinary claims need evidence. The person making the claim should support it.
explanation: Shifts responsibility unfairly.

name: Shifting the Definition (No True Scotsman)
description: Changing the rules to ignore evidence that goes against your claim.
example: No true patriot would criticize their country.
correctedExample: People can love their country and still criticize it.
explanation: It moves the goalposts to protect the claim.

name: Repeating the Claim (Circular Reasoning)
description: Saying the same thing in different words instead of proving it.
example: Lying is wrong because it's immoral.
correctedExample: We should explain why lying is immoral, not just restate the claim.
explanation: It repeats the conclusion as its reason.

name: Trick Question (Loaded Question)
description: Asking something that assumes something untrue or unfair.
example: Why are you so bad at managing your time?
correctedExample: What challenges are you facing with time management?
explanation: The question assumes failure without evidence.

name: Natural Is Better (Appeal to Nature)
description: Saying something is good just because it’s natural.
example: This medicine is natural, so it must be safe.
correctedExample: Natural things can still be harmful. Safety needs testing.
explanation: Natural doesn’t always mean better.

name: You Do It Too (Tu Quoque)
description: Dismissing criticism by accusing the other person of the same thing.
example: You tell me to eat healthy, but I saw you eat chips yesterday!
correctedExample: Even if I ate chips, healthy eating is still a good idea.
explanation: It avoids the issue by attacking the messenger.

name: Let’s Just Meet in the Middle (Middle Ground)
description: Saying the compromise between two sides must be right.
example: One person says the Earth is flat, another says it’s round. So maybe it’s oval.
correctedExample: We need to rely on evidence, not compromise between truth and error.
explanation: Truth isn’t always in the middle.
